hints_html:
Try a substitution.

Try \(u = x^{2}\)

This last integral is one you should know - if you’re still stuck, try using a trig substitution.
hints_latex:
This last integral is one you should know - if you're still stuck, try
using a trig substitution.
hints_raw:
Try a substitution.
Try <math> u = x^{2} </math>
This last integral is one you should know - if you're still stuck, try using a trig substitution.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
Let \(u = x^{2}\) so that \(du = 2xdx\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} \int\frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^{4}}}\, dx &= \frac{1}{2}\int\frac{du}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}} \\ &= \frac{-1}{2}\arccos(u) + C \\ &= \frac{-\arccos(x^{2})}{2} + C\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.

If you forgot the derivative of \(\arccos(x)\), you can use trig substitutions to derive it. The first step though remains the same: Let \(u = x^{2}\) so that \(du = 2xdx\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} \int\frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^{4}}}\, dx = \frac{1}{2}\int\frac{du}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}}\end{aligned}\]

Now, let \(u = \sin\theta\) so \(du = \cos\theta d\theta\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2}\int\frac{du}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}} = \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\cos\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{1 - \sin^{2}\theta}}\end{aligned}\]

Using the trig identity \(\sin^{2}\theta + \cos^{2}\theta =1\), we have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\cos\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{1 - \sin^{2}\theta}} &= \frac{1}{2}\int\frac{\cos\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{\cos^{2}\theta}} \\ &= \frac{1}{2}\int d\theta \\ &= \frac{\theta}{2} + C\\ &= \frac{\arcsin(u)}{2} + C \\ &= \frac{\arcsin(x^{2})}{2} + C\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.

Notice that this answer is different from the answer in the previous part. However, since

\[\begin{aligned} \arccos(x) + \arcsin(x) = \frac{\pi}{2}\end{aligned}\]

the answers are actually the same up to a constant!
sols_latex:
Let $u = x^{2}$ so that $du = 2xdx$. Then

\begin{align*}
\int\frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^{4}}}\, dx  &= \frac{1}{2}\int\frac{du}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}} \\
&= \frac{-1}{2}\arccos(u) + C \\
&= \frac{-\arccos(x^{2})}{2} + C
\end{align*}

completing the question.
sols_raw:
Let <math> u = x^{2} </math> so that <math> du = 2xdx </math>. Then

:<math> \begin{align}
\int\frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^{4}}}\, dx  &= \frac{1}{2}\int\frac{du}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}} \\
&= \frac{-1}{2}\arccos(u) + C \\
&= \frac{-\arccos(x^{2})}{2} + C
\end{align} </math>

completing the question.
If you forgot the derivative of <math> \arccos(x) </math>, you can use trig substitutions to derive it. The first step though remains the same: Let <math> u = x^{2} </math> so that <math> du = 2xdx </math>. Then

:<math> \int\frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^{4}}}\, dx  = \frac{1}{2}\int\frac{du}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}} </math>

Now, let <math> u = \sin\theta </math> so <math> du = \cos\theta d\theta </math>. Then

:<math>
\frac{1}{2}\int\frac{du}{\sqrt{1-u^{2}}} = \frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\cos\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{1 - \sin^{2}\theta}}
</math>

Using the trig identity <math> \sin^{2}\theta + \cos^{2}\theta =1 </math>, we have

:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{1}{2} \int \frac{\cos\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{1 - \sin^{2}\theta}} &= \frac{1}{2}\int\frac{\cos\theta d\theta}{\sqrt{\cos^{2}\theta}} \\
&= \frac{1}{2}\int d\theta \\
&= \frac{\theta}{2} + C\\
&= \frac{\arcsin(u)}{2} + C \\
&= \frac{\arcsin(x^{2})}{2} + C
\end{align}
</math>

completing the question.

''Notice that this answer is different from the answer in the previous part. However, since''

:<math> \arccos(x) + \arcsin(x) = \frac{\pi}{2} </math> 

''the answers are actually the same up to a constant!''
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required.

Evaluate the following integral.

\(\int\frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^{4}}}\, dx\)

Full-Solution Problem. Justify your answers and show all your work.
Simplification of answers is not required.

 Evaluate the following integral.

$\int\frac{x}{\sqrt{1-x^{4}}}\, dx$
